subject: Re: [junit] splitting this list
msgSnippet: ... Todd, I appreciate your concern and have raised that myself, in the past. I would find it difficult to stay on this list myself, if it weren t so low
messageBody:
Bradley, Todd wrote:
> Hi, I'd like to propose a controversial topic, which is to somehow split
> up the JUnit email list into two lists - one for beginners and one for
> intermediate-to-advanced users. I cherish the discussion on this list
> about meaty topics of unit testing and using and extending JUnit. There
> are some very smart people here!
>
> However, I frankly have reached the limit of my tolerance for stupid
> questions in this list. And by "stupid questions" I mean the opposite
> of Eric Raymond's "smart questions"
> (http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html). There seems to be
> no end to the steady stream of new members who sign on and immediately
> ask a question that's already answered in the JUnit FAQ, which every new
> member automatically receives. I know hitting the delete key 5 or 10
> times a day isn't a huge deal, so I guess it's just the principle of it
> all. I consider it rude for people to not have the courtesy to at least
> make an effort to help themselves.
>
> But I thought that rather than just unsubscribing from the list, I'd
> toss this message out to see if anyone else is in the same boat as me.
> There are supposedly over 6000 subscribers, which sure sounds like a big
> enough population to allow some specialization. Alternatively, if
> dividing the junit@yahoogroups.com list isn't likely to happen, does
> anyone know of a similar forum for "intermediate-to-advanced" users of
> JUnit with a better S/N ratio?

Todd, I appreciate your concern and have raised that myself, in the
past. I would find it difficult to stay on this list myself, if it
weren't so low traffic. Also take into consideration the number of posts
we already reject, because the questions are too basic. If we don't
encourage the general public to post their questions, then who will we
have to discuss interesting topics with in a few years?
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
2005 Gordon Pask Award Winner for contribution to Agile practice
Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
